marklogic.body:
Gypski, I don't need to get a permission slip from a doctor to justify my marijuana use, which is likely to be more frequent and heavier than most medical marijuana patients. Â I have been driving on the West Coast, including Washington, over 14,000 miles over eight years, and I have been pulled over exactly once, for a Burnt headlight, and despite smelling like freshly trimmed weed and having NORML stickers on my beat-up Jeep, he gave me a warning and sent me on my way. Â I just don't believe the risk of getting that blood draw increases post I-502.
Find me the current Washington State medical marijuana patient who meets all these criteria: * Driven in the state over a year * Been pulled over by a cop * Been suspected of impairment * Failed a sobriety test * Was taken in for a blood draw * The blood draw came in at >5ng/mL * The suspect was acquitted of DUID in court.
...because that's the person who is at risk under I-502. Â You mention the patient show can only afford a public defender... well, how does that patient escape a DUID at >5ng/mL with a public defender? Â Please, show me the case! Â 100,000 patients, 13 years of medical marijuana, and nobody can find me that 5ng/mL driver acquitted of DUID?
I'll take you up on the challenge if you can provide me a fair counter. Â For instance, if I-502 passes, I'll make sure my ng/mL are above 5ng and drive the length of every freeway in the state and visit the city Hall of your five largest cities over the course of a year. Â In exchange, if I-502 fails, you find me 10,000 patients willing to drop their medical recommendations and carry around an ounce in their pockets at all times next year. Â
